and costly food program for the
Homewood campus next year.

chairman, preliminary contract
negotiations between Saga Co.
and University officials are now

under way and will be concluded
in several weeks.
The company has submitted
plans for random vending, snack
bar, and hot-line operations in
the new Hopkins Union, as well
as cafeteria service and special
function catering in the dorm
dining hall. Submitted also were
plans for a student union
rathskeller which would be

implemented upon relaxation of
state alcoholic beverage control
laws.
The proposed food service will
offer two alternative food plans
to dormitory residents. Both a
five-day, fifteen-meal plan and a
seven-day, twenty-one-meal
plans will be available. Students
will be permitted to change plans
at semester break.

Goodrich favors new Honor plan
By A.P. SMITHWICK
Peter Goodrich, Chairman of
the Honor Commission said he
will vote for the Honor Code
revisions in the Blue Ribbon
Panel report on March 15 but
with reservations.
He opposes certain
recommendations that appear to
drain power from the committee.
But he favors the tougher stances
proposed, such as the mandatory
suspension for one semester of
any student convicted of
cheating on an exam.
The committee has been a
self-perpetuating one and
Goodrich would like to see it
stay that way. Students have
been selected by interviews given

by committee members.
But the BRP report proposes
that the members be elected by
the student body. Goodrich
believes one has a better chance
of screening out good potential
committee members by
interviewing rather than by
elections.
Unreglistic
The BRP requirement that the
trial panel of nine students must
vote unanimously to convict a
student is "unrealistic because
there is always apt, to be one
member not wanting to declare a
strict penalty," said Goodrich. .
He also opposes changing the
present defense procedure. Under
.the present constitution an

indicted student is allowed to
have the aid of a defense council,
who must be a member of the
committee not on the trial panel.
Defense Council
But defense councils work to
uphold the honor code
constitution. They try to extract
all the facts, even if
incriminatory to the student.
The BRP is proposing that a
student be allowed to choose his
defense council from any one in
the undergraduate student body.
According to Goodrich this could
lead to retrogression into the
advocate system. He believes
such a system is inoperable unless
one has a detailed knowledge of
law.

By JACKIE ECKHART
Brass rubbing is a popular hobby in
England especially during the tourist
season when appointments must be made
up to two months ahead for rubbings to
be taken. The vicars of the various Parish
Churches which house the efficies usually
suggest that a contribution be made for
the right to make rubbings of them, and
there are fees of up to SI for the right to
rub the more popular monuments.
The display of brass rubbings in the
Eisenhower Library is part of the two
hundred member collection belonging to
Dr. and Mrs. Verl S. Lewis of Rogers
Fort, Maryland. Most of the rubbings
were made in the winters of 1970 and
1971, when the churches were, as Mrs.
Lewis said, like "walk-in freezers." The
small Parish Churches are not heated
during the week, and so the industrious
visitor, clad in woolen underwear and
gloves, must keel for hours on a cold
stone floor, where most of the
monuments are found. These
monuments, which are two-dimensional
likenesses of members of the small ruling
class of medieval England, are made of

brass set into the stone which covers the
tombs of the nobles. The brass rubbings
themselves are simply paper
reproductions of the raised images which
are created by rubbing the papercovered
figure with pigmented wax, much as
children Make copies of Abraham Lincoln
by covering pennies with paper and
rubbing crayons over them.
The noblemen, the thirteenth to
seventeenth century descendants of the
old Norman families, arranged before
their deaths to have effigies made of brass
placed on their tombs. Many of these
noblemen were great figures in England's
religious history. yet they were buried in
small churches rather than in cathedrals
in order to commerorate people who had
been important to the community. The
size of the brass was dependent upon the
wealth of the nobleman-the more money
he was able to pay, the larger the image
was.
About 7500 monuments exist in
English churches today, but there were
originally close to 100,000. The Civil War
of 1644, the Great Fire of London in
1666, and World War Two bombings were

the main causes for the destruction oi
most of the effigies. The oldest existing
brass is dated 1277 and is of Sir John
D'Abernon of Surrey, whose rubbing
hangs to the right of the front doors of
the library. Among the other rubbings
now in the library are those of Anne
Boleyn and her father, the grandfather of
Elizabeth II.
The armor, clothing, and headresses of
the effigies are accurate, but the features
of the persons are not, for they depended
on the whim of the engraver. The classic
medieval nose was long and straight, and
most of the images have this type of nose,
for the engravers formed the faces as they
desired them to appear. This is part of the
explanation for the remarkable similarity
between many of the faces in the
rubbings, and the other part is that the
same engraver might have done effigies in
more than one church. The clerical class,
which formed an important part of the
ruling elite, is denoted by long robes
while knights wear the armor of then
day. Mrs. Lewis has done a remarkable
study of the headresses of the women
pictured in the monuments, including

hairstyles and head coverings. (She even
notes that the long flowing hair of Cecile
Boleyn signifies spinsterhood.)
The figures in the brasses are portrayed
in a prone position with clasped hands,
for the most part as they would appear in
death, although their eyes are open. The
footrests of the knights are indications of
the manner in which they died-those
who rest their feet on lions died in battle,
while those whose feet rest on dogs did
not. (Sir Roger de Trunpington's dog has
grotesquely long toenails and is biting the
end of Sir Roger's sword.) The knight's
headrests are their helmets, while the
ladies heads rest on cushions.
The impact of these brass rubbings on
the observer is due not only to their
beauty, but also to the sense of history
they convey. The observer finds himself
growing attached to certain figures. The
rubbing of John Tyringham is one of the
smaller ones, yet it is my favorite and
coincidentally the favorite of Mrs. Lewis
and the first she did. John wears a
pointed hat and rests his feet on a dog.
But man's best friend has its tongue
sticking out.

The meaning seems almost too obvious:
-physical contact as the basis of
communication. The maid Anna is the
only person who is capable of such
communication. She shows "normal"
emotion (that is, tears) only in one scene,
and yet she is the only person who can
communicate truthfully. One begins to
see the falseness in the outward signs of
the two sisters' emotionalism. It seems
that all the tears in the world mean very
little.
One gets the feeling that Bergman is
blurring some concepts that are normally
distinguishable. Like the still photograph,
his film seems to freeze the movement'of
time and replace it with the movement of

By MICHAEL BERESTON
Usually around this time of
year sports fans all over are sizing
the NBA playoffs or wondering
whether it will be the Bruins or
the Canadians to take the Stanley
Cup.
If this isn't satisfying enough,
one can toy over the upcoming
baseball season, wondering who's
going.to cop the National League
pennant. Onc asks, "what about
the American League?" and a
round of snorts- and laughter
penetrates all those present.
After all, the American League
is the no hit, gate declining junior
circuit whose very comparison to
the excitement of the National
League provokes amusement.
This winter, though, the
American League did something
about it; the designated pinch
hitter (DPH) rule was their first
retaliation.
There is no explanation
necessary as to why the "senior
circuit" has rejected the idea.

The National League is doing fine
at the gate, batting averages are
up, and regardless of a few
skeptical premonitions of doom
the tuture looks bright.
A good hitting pitcher like
Bob Gibson or Milt Pappas, if
perhaps rare, is still an intriguing
aspect to the game. What a gteat
thrill it must be for Cardinal fans
when Gibson hurls a shut out and
wins the game on his own home
run. Critics are already asking
what would have happened if the
new "DPH" rule had been in
effect when Babe Ruth was a
pitcher. Chances are his
thundering bat would never have
been given a chance to work its
magic.
Further cries have been made
for the .abused sacredness of the
"grand old game." How could
the American League do such a
thing? Change in baseball has
always been slow in coming,
often due to the indignation of
outmoded traditionalists.

The American League was
audacious, but change has been
.ong overdue. Granted sports
have been far too specialized and
the new rule only strengthens
this claim. No longer do pitchers
pitclt both ends of a
doubleheader. There aren't any
"Iron Man McGinnity's" around
today. God forbid if a lefthanded
swinger conies up in a situation
against your best righty. Time to
drag your southpaw fast ball man
from the bullpen for one pitch
before you go to you curve ball
specialist.
Maybe today's ballplayer isn't
as good as his predecessor, but
perhaps today's athletes are so
much batter that specialization is
required.
In any event, the fact are that
the American League has
adopted the rule and managers
allover are dickering with new
strategems to employ. The men
with , the wicked bats whose
bodies become too old and slow

to handle the field, are finding
new homes. Likewise, for those
who have never had good gloves.
Injury prone stars like Rico
Carty, Orlando Cepeda, and Al
Kaline may rind the new rule as
significant to lengthen their
careers.
Others like aging California
Angels superstar Frank Robinson
are disturbed at the idea of not
being given the opportunity to
do it all in the field as well as at
bat.
Managers will no longer have
to lose the bat of their superstar
at one end of a doubleheader.
The fans will no longer have to
sigh when it would have been the
pitcher's turn to swing the stick.
While the American Legion, Babe
Ruth and little Leagues refuse to
adopt the rule, some leading
colleges have already consented.
Sooner or later it should become
uniform procedure and if that
happens, baseball will never be
the same again.

Task force formed to clean up Stony Run
By MARTIN FRENCH
A new multi-neighborhood
task force has been formed to
improve and preserve Stony Run
and its adjacent parklands.
The task force was convened
on February 27 to coordinate
various community organzations
in their efforts to Fight water
pollution, erosion, and general
deterioration of the Stony Run
area.
Stony Run originates on the
northern City line, and with its
tributary Homeland Run affects
five neighborhoods and seven
educational institutions,
including Loyola—Notre Dame
and Johns Hopkins University.
Erosion of the stream banks and
occasional flooding most concern
the institutions, while the
neighborhoods' residents are
most disturbed by sewage in
Stony Run and trash in Wyman
Park and Stony Run Park.
Ms. Peggy Wright, convenor of
the Stony Run task force, made
the introductory statement of
purpose: "We are here because
we believe there are serious
problems which threaten the
stream and its surrounding

parkland to remain as
undeveloped and natural as
possible."
Wright's statement was
indirectly challenged by David
Cearfoss of the Baltimore Water
Resources Department, who
pointed out, "Stony Run is an
urban stream, and as such is not
going to be 'natural' like a stream
up mi Garrett. County. The Run
is already developed, to the
extent that it is used for storm

drainage, and so can not be
returned to its original state."
One problem which has been
created along Stony Run is
erosion and silting due to
landfills for new playing fields at
Gilman and Friends' schools. The
landfills, very similar to Hopkins'
new fields on the West Campus,
have both narrowed the
stream bed and removed some
flood plains, with the result that
Stony Run floods elsewhere and

erodes it banks more. This can be
seen on Hopkins' West Campus,
as trees are being undercut and
fall into the Run, and in Wyman
Park where concrete walls have
been weakened and destroyed,
exposing the banks to further
erosion.
Cearfoss proposed that the task
force consider the "Chinquapin
Run treatment" for Stony Run,
which he explained. "Over there
we've put in gabians— rock-filled

galvanized heavy wire
baskets—along the stream.
They're not 'natural' but they
protect the banks from erosion,"
Cearfoss stated. The task force
members indicated that gabians
would be preferable to concrete
walls, but might be too much
development for their
conservationist tastes.
On the matter of trash in and
around Stony Run, task force
members commended Bryn Mawr
School for its beautification
program, and Ian Jewett of
Gilman School mentioned the
possibility of getting Gilman
boys to work on the streamside.
Cearfoss noted, "It's an
interesting psychological
phenomenon that when we get a
stream area green, people don't
dump." Robert Aro of the City
Parks Department, Druid Hill
Division, added,"The Stony Run
area doesn't get priority in park
maintenance partly because of
funds, but that is due to the lack
of public interest in the area, at
least as perceived by the planners
and political representatives.
People have to show that they
care. about Stony Run."

By JACKIE ECKHART
Brass rubbing is a popular hobby in
England especially during the tourist
season when appointments must be made
up to two months ahead for rubbings to
be taken. The vicars of the various Parish
Churches which house the efficies usually
suggest that a contribution be made for
the right to make rubbings of them, and
there are fees of up to SI for the right to
rub the more popular monuments.
The display of brass rubbings in the
Eisenhower Library is part of the two
hundred member collection belonging to
Dr. and Mrs. Verl S. Lewis of Rogers
Fort, Maryland. Most of the rubbings
were made in the winters of 1970 and
1971, when the churches were, as Mrs.
Lewis said, like "walk-in freezers." The
small Parish Churches are not heated
during the week, and so the industrious
visitor, clad in woolen underwear and
gloves, must keel for hours on a cold
stone floor, where most of the
monuments are found. These
monuments, which are two-dimensional
likenesses of members of the small ruling
class of medieval England, are made of

brass set into the stone which covers the
tombs of the nobles. The brass rubbings
themselves are simply paper
reproductions of the raised images which
are created by rubbing the papercovered
figure with pigmented wax, much as
children Make copies of Abraham Lincoln
by covering pennies with paper and
rubbing crayons over them.
The noblemen, the thirteenth to
seventeenth century descendants of the
old Norman families, arranged before
their deaths to have effigies made of brass
placed on their tombs. Many of these
noblemen were great figures in England's
religious history. yet they were buried in
small churches rather than in cathedrals
in order to commerorate people who had
been important to the community. The
size of the brass was dependent upon the
wealth of the nobleman-the more money
he was able to pay, the larger the image
was.
About 7500 monuments exist in
English churches today, but there were
originally close to 100,000. The Civil War
of 1644, the Great Fire of London in
1666, and World War Two bombings were

the main causes for the destruction oi
most of the effigies. The oldest existing
brass is dated 1277 and is of Sir John
D'Abernon of Surrey, whose rubbing
hangs to the right of the front doors of
the library. Among the other rubbings
now in the library are those of Anne
Boleyn and her father, the grandfather of
Elizabeth II.
The armor, clothing, and headresses of
the effigies are accurate, but the features
of the persons are not, for they depended
on the whim of the engraver. The classic
medieval nose was long and straight, and
most of the images have this type of nose,
for the engravers formed the faces as they
desired them to appear. This is part of the
explanation for the remarkable similarity
between many of the faces in the
rubbings, and the other part is that the
same engraver might have done effigies in
more than one church. The clerical class,
which formed an important part of the
ruling elite, is denoted by long robes
while knights wear the armor of then
day. Mrs. Lewis has done a remarkable
study of the headresses of the women
pictured in the monuments, including

hairstyles and head coverings. (She even
notes that the long flowing hair of Cecile
Boleyn signifies spinsterhood.)
The figures in the brasses are portrayed
in a prone position with clasped hands,
for the most part as they would appear in
death, although their eyes are open. The
footrests of the knights are indications of
the manner in which they died-those
who rest their feet on lions died in battle,
while those whose feet rest on dogs did
not. (Sir Roger de Trunpington's dog has
grotesquely long toenails and is biting the
end of Sir Roger's sword.) The knight's
headrests are their helmets, while the
ladies heads rest on cushions.
The impact of these brass rubbings on
the observer is due not only to their
beauty, but also to the sense of history
they convey. The observer finds himself
growing attached to certain figures. The
rubbing of John Tyringham is one of the
smaller ones, yet it is my favorite and
coincidentally the favorite of Mrs. Lewis
and the first she did. John wears a
pointed hat and rests his feet on a dog.
But man's best friend has its tongue
sticking out.

The meaning seems almost too obvious:
-physical contact as the basis of
communication. The maid Anna is the
only person who is capable of such
communication. She shows "normal"
emotion (that is, tears) only in one scene,
and yet she is the only person who can
communicate truthfully. One begins to
see the falseness in the outward signs of
the two sisters' emotionalism. It seems
that all the tears in the world mean very
little.

blurring some concepts that are normally
distinguishable. Like the still photograph,
his film seems to freeze the movement'of
time and replace it with the movement of
space. Also appearance and reality is
unified. Tears are not as appearance of
emotion; they are, simply, false emotion.
Maria's dress is not a signifier of what
Maria really is; the dress is Maria-all
seductive lace and false physicality.
Cries and Whispers is a film that pulls
the viewer into the frame. One is forced
to touch, to move about in a realm of
space without time. Physicality stands as
the film's dominant motif and Berman's
technique stands hand in hand with the
meaning. The film is a masterpiece of the
unity of style and content.

By MICHAEL BERESTON
Usually around this time of
year sports fans all over are sizing
the NBA playoffs or wondering
whether it will be the Bruins or
the Canadians to take the Stanley
Cup.
If this isn't satisfying enough,
one can toy over the upcoming
baseball season, wondering who's
going.to cop the National League
pennant. Onc asks, "what about
the American League?" and a
round of snorts- and laughter
penetrates all those present.
After all, the American League
is the no hit, gate declining junior
circuit whose very comparison to
the excitement of the National
League provokes amusement.
This winter, though, the
American League did something
about it; the designated pinch
hitter (DPH) rule was their first
retaliation.
There is no explanation
necessary as to why the "senior
circuit" has rejected the idea.

The National League is doing fine
at the gate, batting averages are
up, and regardless of a few
skeptical premonitions of doom
the tuture looks bright.
A good hitting pitcher like
Bob Gibson or Milt Pappas, if
perhaps rare, is still an intriguing
aspect to the game. What a gteat
thrill it must be for Cardinal fans
when Gibson hurls a shut out and
wins the game on his own home
run. Critics are already asking
what would have happened if the
new "DPH" rule had been in
effect when Babe Ruth was a
pitcher. Chances are his
thundering bat would never have
been given a chance to work its
magic.
Further cries have been made
for the .abused sacredness of the
"grand old game." How could
the American League do such a
thing? Change in baseball has
always been slow in coming,
often due to the indignation of
outmoded traditionalists.

The American League was
audacious, but change has been
.ong overdue. Granted sports
have been far too specialized and
the new rule only strengthens
this claim. No longer do pitchers
pitclt both ends of a
doubleheader. There aren't any
"Iron Man McGinnity's" around
today. God forbid if a lefthanded
swinger conies up in a situation
against your best righty. Time to
drag your southpaw fast ball man
from the bullpen for one pitch
before you go to you curve ball
specialist.
Maybe today's ballplayer isn't
as good as his predecessor, but
perhaps today's athletes are so
much batter that specialization is
required.
In any event, the fact are that
the American League has
adopted the rule and managers
allover are dickering with new
strategems to employ. The men
with , the wicked bats whose
bodies become too old and slow

to handle the field, are finding
new homes. Likewise, for those
who have never had good gloves.
Injury prone stars like Rico
Carty, Orlando Cepeda, and Al
Kaline may rind the new rule as
significant to lengthen their
careers.
Others like aging California
Angels superstar Frank Robinson
are disturbed at the idea of not
being given the opportunity to
do it all in the field as well as at
bat.
Managers will no longer have
to lose the bat of their superstar
at one end of a doubleheader.
The fans will no longer have to
sigh when it would have been the
pitcher's turn to swing the stick.
While the American Legion, Babe
Ruth and little Leagues refuse to
adopt the rule, some leading
colleges have already consented.
Sooner or later it should become
uniform procedure and if that
happens, baseball will never be
the same again.

Task force formed to clean up Stony Run
By MARTIN FRENCH
A new multi-neighborhood
task force has been formed to
improve and preserve Stony Run
and its adjacent parklands.
The task force was convened
on February 27 to coordinate
various community organzations
in their efforts to Fight water
pollution, erosion, and general
deterioration of the Stony Run
area.
Stony Run originates on the
northern City line, and with its
tributary Homeland Run affects
five neighborhoods and seven
educational institutions,
including Loyola—Notre Dame
and Johns Hopkins University.
Erosion of the stream banks and
occasional flooding most concern
the institutions, while the
neighborhoods' residents are
most disturbed by sewage in
Stony Run and trash in Wyman
Park and Stony Run Park.
Ms. Peggy Wright, convenor of
the Stony Run task force, made
the introductory statement of
purpose: "We are here because
we believe there are serious
problems which threaten the
stream and its surrounding

parkland to remain as
undeveloped and natural as
possible."
Wright's statement was
indirectly challenged by David
Cearfoss of the Baltimore Water
Resources Department, who
pointed out, "Stony Run is an
urban stream, and as such is not
going to be 'natural' like a stream
up mi Garrett. County. The Run
is already developed, to the
extent that it is used for storm

drainage, and so can not be
returned to its original state."
One problem which has been
created along Stony Run is
erosion and silting due to
landfills for new playing fields at
Gilman and Friends' schools. The
landfills, very similar to Hopkins'
new fields on the West Campus,
have both narrowed the
stream bed and removed some
flood plains, with the result that
Stony Run floods elsewhere and

erodes it banks more. This can be
seen on Hopkins' West Campus,
as trees are being undercut and
fall into the Run, and in Wyman
Park where concrete walls have
been weakened and destroyed,
exposing the banks to further
erosion.
Cearfoss proposed that the task
force consider the "Chinquapin
Run treatment" for Stony Run,
which he explained. "Over there
we've put in gabians— rock-filled

galvanized heavy wire
baskets—along the stream.
They're not 'natural' but they
protect the banks from erosion,"
Cearfoss stated. The task force
members indicated that gabians
would be preferable to concrete
walls, but might be too much
development for their
conservationist tastes.
On the matter of trash in and
around Stony Run, task force
members commended Bryn Mawr
School for its beautification
program, and Ian Jewett of
Gilman School mentioned the
possibility of getting Gilman
boys to work on the streamside.
Cearfoss noted, "It's an
interesting psychological
phenomenon that when we get a
stream area green, people don't
dump." Robert Aro of the City
Parks Department, Druid Hill
Division, added,"The Stony Run
area doesn't get priority in park
maintenance partly because of
funds, but that is due to the lack
of public interest in the area, at
least as perceived by the planners
and political representatives.
People have to show that they
care. about Stony Run."
